descriptionSet.description: This photograph shows the War memorial in remembrance of those fallen in First World War between 1915 and 1918 (Monumento ai Caduti). It is located at the Piazza Umberto I in the town of Crotone, today the capital of the province with the same name in south-east Italy.

inscription.text: CROTONE - Piazza Umberto I - Monumento ai Caduti

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: Front of Eid card showing Crotone war memorial

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: CROTONE - Piazza Umberto I - Monumento ai Caduti

description-en: This photograph shows the War memorial in remembrance of those fallen in First World War between 1915 and 1918 (Monumento ai Caduti). It is located at the Piazza Umberto I in the town of Crotone, today the capital of the province with the same name in south-east Italy. (ma)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The reverse of this image used as a postcard has Urdu writing on it. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It seems that such Eid cards have been created from blank picture cards imported in bulk from Europe. They feature photographs of locations and objects as alien to Indian Eid as Greek and Italian sculptures and monuments, besides European cinema and theatre stars of the time! (Yousuf Saeed) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The War memorial (Monumento ai Caduti 1915-1918) was commissioned by the City Council, realized by Giuseppe Ciocchetti and erected in 1925. (ma)

related hyperlinks: http://www.comune.crotone.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeAttachment.php/L/IT/D/0%252F7%252F1%252FD.634379b45481b3e45d63/P/BLOB%3AID%3D2536, last accessed 2012-01-13, in-depth description of the War memorial (ma)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)
related literature: Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html (6.4.2011)(gs)

related literature: Wehbe, Rana, Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality, (undated) American University of Beirut, Lebanon, http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf (gs)
